text:
HAZEL SIVE: At the end
of this class exercise,

you should be able to deal
with these aspects of PCR--

designing a primer,
understanding what a primer is,

and using those
to figure out how
to PCR amplify a DNA molecule.

Today in our discussion,
we've covered four topics--

genetic engineering,
restriction endonucleases,

the notion of a
vector and ligation,

and the polymerase
chain reaction.

You should at this
point have finished some
of your second problem set.

And this discussion
will allow you

to finish the rest of
your second problem set
for this course.

This is the last of
our discussions today.

Over the course of
these five meetings,

we have talked about
the molecules of life.

We've talked about the
cell and how it works,

information transfer in biology,
inheritance and genetics,
and building with DNA.

I've given you background
to these topics that

are some of the most
pivotal in modern biology

and the ones that you will
really need to know in order

to succeed in the
introductory biology course
at MIT or elsewhere.

You've had to have a
lot of different ways

to take the concepts
that I've given you

in these lectures
and work with them,

so that they should
become familiar to you.
You've had class exercises.

There are two problem
sets, as I mentioned.

You should be working
through the second one now.

There is a final
exam that you will

do when you've finished
your second problem set.

But really, the
important thing is

that through our
discussions, I hope
you have got lots of knowledge.

I hope you feel much more
empowered to understand

the bits of biology
that might not

have been so familiar
to you when we started
having our conversations.

And I feel sure
that with completion

of the material in
this course, you

are ready for your
next biology course,

whether it is at
MIT or elsewhere.
Thank you very much.

It's been a real
pleasure to have
these discussions with you.
